Award.AwardTitle: Next Generation In Situ Measurements of Stratospheric Aerosol
Award.AbstractNarration:
Small particles in the stratosphere (10-30 km) affect the ozone layer that protects live from harmful ultraviolet solar radiation and also affect climate. These stratospheric aerosols are controlled by volcanic, natural and human activities that produce sulfur containing gases or particles. The US has the longest 40-year record of the vertical distribution of particles that has been made over Laramie, WY that has been invaluable to calibrate models and validate satellites. There is a prisoning need to continue this long-term record, modernize the instruments - making them better, lighter and cheaper and maintain US leadership in instrumentation and science. This proposal achieves this by developing a compact modern commercial sensor and mentoring a young PI to take over the leadership and transition operations to Boulder, CO.

The project expands the long-term balloon borne measurements of stratospheric aerosols up to 30 km to build upon a unique 40-year record of profiles of aerosol concentration and size. The site will be transitioned from Laramie, WY to Boulder, CO and the plan includes the mentoring a new leader (currently co-PI). The instrument payload will be modernized by adapting a commercial optical particle counters (Lighthouse Remote 3104 clean room particle spectrometer) that will extend the capability and reduce size, weight and costs and enhance deployability. The aerosol profile is crucial for the understanding of long-term stratospheric aerosol-chemistry interactions, satellite retrievals and validation and troposphere-stratosphere coupling response to climate change. The project was re-scoped to focus on the design and validation of a next generation aerosol profiling system and build 2 prototypes and perform limited flight-testing and validation against current instrument. The project will also begin the transition of the activity to Boulder, CO including hardware and a new PI. The transition effort should result in competitive future science proposals and create long-term synergistic monitoring of balloon borne aerosol, trace-gas and water profile measurements for atmospheric chemistry, climate and satellite validation centered in Boulder, CO and assert US leadership.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Stratospheric aerosol is a persistent yet highly variable component of the stratosphere. It has impacts on radiation and stratospheric ozone, both of which affect climate. The source of these aerosol is naturally occurring sulfur bearing molecules, explosive volcanic activity, and meteoritic smoke. Because of their impacts on the chemical and radiative balance of the stratosphere such aerosol have been measured regularly since the early 1970s using remote ground based instruments, balloon-borne and aircraft-borne in situ instruments, and remote satellite instruments. The goal of this award was to develop new instruments and scientific expertise to extend the capability to make in situ stratospheric aerosol size and concentration measurements using instruments deployed on balloon platforms. Such measurements have been made from a few locations since the early 1970s, but the instruments for these measurements are at the end of their lifetime. The outcomes from this award have established new capability in this area, a capability that remains unique in the world. Such measurements are important for comparison to the remote, ground based and satellite, instruments and with global climate models.

All global climate models must account for stratospheric aerosol, both non-volcanic and volcanic. Typically, this is done with aerosol climatologies from satellite instruments, but these instruments are not well suited to provide some of the physical parameters required by the models, such as aerosol surface area for ozone interactions and aerosol cross section for radiation interactions. Other models derive their own aerosol from primary emissions. In the first case in situ data are required to provide confidence in the aerosol products derived from the satellite measurements for the aerosol climatologies. In the second case the in situ data provide an unparalleled data set for comparison with the model derived aerosol. Thus the instruments developed here will be used to further the understanding of how stratospheric aerosol, both non-volcanic and volcanic, will be incorporated into future climate predictions, and their concomitant societal impacts. The new in situ instruments are already employed for comparison with the current suite of satellite instruments employed in measuring stratospheric aerosol.

Aside from the instrument development work, which has provided a complete set of instruments to extend stratospheric aerosol measurement capability, two papers were published to further our understanding of how to best to analyzed in situ stratospheric aerosol measurements.

The first paper emphasizes the importance of laboratory measurements to establish the counting efficiency of in situ instruments at each aerosol size measured. With such information significantly improved agreement was found between the historical in situ measurements and remote satellite measurements. Establishing that the in situ measurements reproduce the fundamental remote satellite measurements of extinction, across several wavelengths and several satellite instruments, indicates that both types of measurements are providing realistic characteristics of stratospheric aerosol. This agreement allows the in situ measurements to become a test bed for algorithms which derive aerosol surface area and cross section from remote satellite instruments.

The second paper analyzes in situ measurements made by optical particle counters (OPCs) at Laramie, Wyoming from 2008-2018 for the purpose of assessing the sensitivity of the stratospheric aerosol phase function to the aerosol size distribution (ASD) model used to fit the measurements. The two unimodal ASD models investigated were the uni-modal lognormal (UMLN) and gamma distribution models. Comparing the values for the fits at altitudes of 20 and 25 km shows that the UMLN distribution better represents the OPC measurements; however, the gamma distribution fits the Community Aerosol and Radiation Model for Atmospheres (CARMA) sectional aerosol microphysics model results better than the UMLN model. Comparing phase functions derived from the UMLN distributions fit to OPC data with gamma distributions fit to CARMA model results, at the location of the OPC measurements, shows a satisfying agreement (?5%) between the aerosol measurements and the aerosol model. This helps to support the use of the CARMA model to extend the local in situ measurements to the global scale required for climate models.
